photo.title: Pont Alexandre III

photo.description: More views of the magnificent Pont Alexandre III Pont Alexandre III is an arch bridge that spans the Seine, connecting the Champs-Élysées quarter and the Invalides and Eiffel Tower quarter, widely regarded as the most ornate, extravagant bridge in Paris. The bridge, with its exuberant Art Nouveau lamps, cherubs, nymphs and winged horses at either end, was built between 1896 and 1900. It is named after Tsar Alexander III, who had concluded the Franco-Russian Alliance in 1892. His son Nicholas II laid the foundation stone in October 1896. The style of the bridge reflects that of the Grand Palais, to which it leads on the right bank. The construction of the bridge is a marvel of 19th century engineering, consisting of a six-metre high single span steel arch. The design, by the architects Joseph Cassien-Bernard and Gaston Cousin, was subject to strict controls that prevented the bridge from obscuring the view of the Champs-Élysées or the Invalides. The bridge was built by the engineers Jean Résal and Amédée d'Alby and inaugurated in 1900 for the Universal Exhibition (as were the nearby Grand Palais and Petit Palais). The Pont Alexandre III is classified as a historical monument. Numerous sculptors provided the sculpture that features prominently in the bridge. Four gilt-bronze statues of Fames watch over the bridge, supported on massive 17-meter socles, that provide stabilizing counterweight for the arch, without interfering with monumental views. The socles are crowned by Fames restraining Pegasus : on the Right Bank, Renommée des Sciences (&quot;Fame of the Sciences&quot;) and the Renommée des Arts (&quot;Fame of the Arts&quot;) both by Emmanuel Frémiet; at their bases, La France Contemporaine (&quot;Contemporary France&quot;) by Gustave Michel and France de Charlemagne (&quot;France of Charlemagne&quot;) by Alfred Lenoir. The lions groups are by Georges Gardet. On the Left Bank, the Renommée du Commerce (&quot;Fame of Commerce&quot;) by Pierre Granet and the Renommée de l'Industrie (&quot;Fame of Industry&quot;) by Clément Steiner; at their bases France de la Renaissance (&quot;France of the Renaissance&quot;) by Jules Coutan and La France de Louis XIV (&quot;France of Louis XIV&quot;) by Laurent Honoré Marqueste. The lions groups are by Jules Dalou. At the centres of the arches, Nymphs of the Seine with the arms of France correspond with Nymphs of the Neva with the arms of Imperial Russia on the other face; both are executed in hammered copper over forms by Georges Récipon.
photo.tags: bridge paris france eiffeltower toureiffel boattrip iledefrance pontalexandreiii bateauxmouches riverseine rivercruise universalexhibition francorussianalliance tsaralexanderiii josephcassienbernard gastoncousin jeanrésal amédéedalby
photo.title: Pont Alexandre III

photo.description: More views of the magnificent Pont Alexandre III Also boats below the bridge. Grand Palais beside the bridge Grand Palais, &quot;Great Palace&quot; in English, is a glass and Art-Nouveau ironwork building located in the 8th arondissement of París. Construction was begun in 1897, for the Paris Exhibition of 1891. &quot;Monument consecrated by the Republic for the glory of the French Arts&quot; as written on its walls, its original purpose was to collect the greatest artistic works from the French capital. On June 12, 1975, the central nave of the building was registered as a historic monument. On the 6th of November, 2000, the entire Great Palace achieved this protection. Over time, it has had various uses. It was closed from 1993 to 2005 after one of the glass ceiling panels fell. Now it is restored and its over 400,000 sq. ft. of space regularly host picture exhibition &quot;salons&quot;. Pont Alexandre III is an arch bridge that spans the Seine, connecting the Champs-Élysées quarter and the Invalides and Eiffel Tower quarter, widely regarded as the most ornate, extravagant bridge in Paris. The bridge, with its exuberant Art Nouveau lamps, cherubs, nymphs and winged horses at either end, was built between 1896 and 1900. The style of the bridge reflects that of the Grand Palais, to which it leads on the right bank. The construction of the bridge is a marvel of 19th century engineering, consisting of a six-metre high single span steel arch. The design, by the architects Joseph Cassien-Bernard and Gaston Cousin, was subject to strict controls that prevented the bridge from obscuring the view of the Champs-Élysées or the Invalides. The bridge was built by the engineers Jean Résal and Amédée d'Alby and inaugurated in 1900 for the Universal Exhibition (as were the nearby Grand Palais and Petit Palais). The Pont Alexandre III is classified as a historical monument. Numerous sculptors provided the sculpture that features prominently in the bridge. Four gilt-bronze statues of Fames watch over the bridge, supported on massive 17-meter socles, that provide stabilizing counterweight for the arch, without interfering with monumental views. The socles are crowned by Fames restraining Pegasus : on the Right Bank, Renommée des Sciences (&quot;Fame of the Sciences&quot;) and the Renommée des Arts (&quot;Fame of the Arts&quot;) both by Emmanuel Frémiet; at their bases, La France Contemporaine (&quot;Contemporary France&quot;) by Gustave Michel and France de Charlemagne (&quot;France of Charlemagne&quot;) by Alfred Lenoir. The lions groups are by Georges Gardet. On the Left Bank, the Renommée du Commerce (&quot;Fame of Commerce&quot;) by Pierre Granet and the Renommée de l'Industrie (&quot;Fame of Industry&quot;) by Clément Steiner; at their bases France de la Renaissance (&quot;France of the Renaissance&quot;) by Jules Coutan and La France de Louis XIV (&quot;France of Louis XIV&quot;) by Laurent Honoré Marqueste. The lions groups are by Jules Dalou. At the centres of the arches, Nymphs of the Seine with the arms of France correspond with Nymphs of the Neva with the arms of Imperial Russia on the other face; both are executed in hammered copper over forms by Georges Récipon.

On the Left Bank, the Renommée du Commerce (&quot;Fame of Commerce&quot;) by Pierre Granet and the Renommée de l'Industrie (&quot;Fame of Industry&quot;) by Clément Steiner; at their bases France de la Renaissance (&quot;France of the Renaissance&quot;) by Jules Coutan and La France de Louis XIV (&quot;France of Louis XIV&quot;) by Laurent Honoré Marqueste. The lions groups are by Jules Dalou. At the centres of the arches, Nymphs of the Seine with the arms of France correspond with Nymphs of the Neva with the arms of Imperial Russia on the other face; both are executed in hammered copper over forms by Georges Récipon.

photo.description: More views of the magnificent Pont Alexandre III Another winged horse statue. Pont Alexandre III is an arch bridge that spans the Seine, connecting the Champs-Élysées quarter and the Invalides and Eiffel Tower quarter, widely regarded as the most ornate, extravagant bridge in Paris. The bridge, with its exuberant Art Nouveau lamps, cherubs, nymphs and winged horses at either end, was built between 1896 and 1900. It is named after Tsar Alexander III, who had concluded the Franco-Russian Alliance in 1892. His son Nicholas II laid the foundation stone in October 1896. The style of the bridge reflects that of the Grand Palais, to which it leads on the right bank. The construction of the bridge is a marvel of 19th century engineering, consisting of a six-metre high single span steel arch. The design, by the architects Joseph Cassien-Bernard and Gaston Cousin, was subject to strict controls that prevented the bridge from obscuring the view of the Champs-Élysées or the Invalides. The bridge was built by the engineers Jean Résal and Amédée d'Alby and inaugurated in 1900 for the Universal Exhibition (as were the nearby Grand Palais and Petit Palais). The Pont Alexandre III is classified as a historical monument. Numerous sculptors provided the sculpture that features prominently in the bridge. Four gilt-bronze statues of Fames watch over the bridge, supported on massive 17-meter socles, that provide stabilizing counterweight for the arch, without interfering with monumental views. The socles are crowned by Fames restraining Pegasus : on the Right Bank, Renommée des Sciences (&quot;Fame of the Sciences&quot;) and the Renommée des Arts (&quot;Fame of the Arts&quot;) both by Emmanuel Frémiet; at their bases, La France Contemporaine (&quot;Contemporary France&quot;) by Gustave Michel and France de Charlemagne (&quot;France of Charlemagne&quot;) by Alfred Lenoir. The lions groups are by Georges Gardet. On the Left Bank, the Renommée du Commerce (&quot;Fame of Commerce&quot;) by Pierre Granet and the Renommée de l'Industrie (&quot;Fame of Industry&quot;) by Clément Steiner; at their bases France de la Renaissance (&quot;France of the Renaissance&quot;) by Jules Coutan and La France de Louis XIV (&quot;France of Louis XIV&quot;) by Laurent Honoré Marqueste. The lions groups are by Jules Dalou. At the centres of the arches, Nymphs of the Seine with the arms of France correspond with Nymphs of the Neva with the arms of Imperial Russia on the other face; both are executed in hammered copper over forms by Georges Récipon.

photo.description: More views of the magnificent Pont Alexandre III Boats next to the bridge. Grand Palais beside the bridge Grand Palais, &quot;Great Palace&quot; in English, is a glass and Art-Nouveau ironwork building located in the 8th arondissement of París. Construction was begun in 1897, for the Paris Exhibition of 1891. &quot;Monument consecrated by the Republic for the glory of the French Arts&quot; as written on its walls, its original purpose was to collect the greatest artistic works from the French capital. On June 12, 1975, the central nave of the building was registered as a historic monument. On the 6th of November, 2000, the entire Great Palace achieved this protection. Over time, it has had various uses. It was closed from 1993 to 2005 after one of the glass ceiling panels fell. Now it is restored and its over 400,000 sq. ft. of space regularly host picture exhibition &quot;salons&quot;. photo.description: <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">The Pont Alexandre III<a><b> is an arch bridge that spans the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiSeine" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Seine<a><b>, connecting the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiChamps-Élysées" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Champs-Élysées<a><b> quarter and the <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiLes_Invalides" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Invalides<a><b> and <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Eiffel Tower<a><b> quarter, widely regarded as the most ornate, extravagant bridge in <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiParis" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Paris<a><b>. Source: <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a><b>

photo.title: Pont Alexandre III, River Seine, Paris

photo.description: Quartier du Triangle d'Or ◆◇◆◇◆◇◆◇◆◇◆◇◆◇◆◇◆◇◆ Le pont Alexandre III, d'une longueur de 154 mètres pour une largeur 45 mètres, fut construit par les ingénieurs Jean Résal et Amédée Alby pour l'Exposition Universelle de 1900 La première pierre est posée par le tsar Nicolas II, fils d'Alexandre III de Russie en 1896, le pont était destiné à symboliser l'amitié franco-russe C'est le président de la République Emile Loubet qui l'inaugure Il est constitué d'une arche métallique de 107,50 mètres, encadrée de deux viaducs de 22,50 mètres chacun Le pont possède, sur toute sa longueur, une riche décoration en fonte qui participe à sa renommée Le Pont Alexandre III relie l'esplanade des Invalides à l'avenue Wilson Churchill

photo.description: This Art Nouveau bridge was designed by architects Joseph Cassien-Bernard and Gaston Cousin and built by Jean Résal and Amédée d'Alby between 1896-1900. The bridge was named in honour of Tsar Alexander III, who had concluded the Franco-Russian Alliance in 1892. The bridge is an arch bridge with four 17-meter socles, acting as counterweights, atop of each of these is a large gilt statue. Taken in the 8e Arrondissement
photo.tags: paris artnouveau pontalexandreiii archbridge 8earrondissement francorussianalliance tsaralexanderiii josephcassienbernard gastoncousin jeanrésal amédéedalby 170912

photo.description: This Art Nouveau bridge was designed by architects Joseph Cassien-Bernard and Gaston Cousin and built by Jean Résal and Amédée d'Alby between 1896-1900. The bridge was named in honour of Tsar Alexander III, who had concluded the Franco-Russian Alliance in 1892. The bridge is an arch bridge with four 17-meter socles, acting as counterweights, atop of each of these is a large gilt statue. Taken in the 8e Arrondissement

Source: <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a><b>

photo.description: Der Pont Alexandre III (frz. für Brücke Alexander III.) ist eine im Stil des im Neobarocks errichtete Seinebrücke in Paris. Die 115 m lange Brücke erinnert an das 1894 besiegelte französisch-russische Bündnis. Sie trägt den Namen des Zaren Alexander III (1845–1894), der den Vertrag angeregt hatte. Die Errichtung begann 1897, das Bauwerk war rechtzeitig zur Pariser Weltausstellung im Jahre 1900 vollendet. <a href"http:de.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" rel"nofollow">de.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III<a> The bridge, with its exuberant Art Nouveau lamps, cherubs, nymphs and winged horses at either end, was built between 1896 and 1900. It is named after Tsar Alexander III, who had concluded the Franco-Russian Alliance in 1892. His son Nicholas II laid the foundation stone in October 1896. The style of the bridge reflects that of the Grand Palais, to which it leads on the right bank. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III<a>

Source: <b><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPont_Alexandre_III" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a><b>

photo.description: The <b><a href"https:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Eiffel Tower<a><b> (<b><a href"https:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">La Tour Eiffel<a><b>) is an iron lattice tower located on the Champ de Mars in Paris, named after the engineer Gustave Eiffel, whose company designed and built the tower. Erected in 1889 as the entrance arch to the 1889 World's Fair, it has become both a global cultural icon of France and one of the most recognizable structures in the world. <b><a href"https:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">The Tower<a><b> is the tallest structure in Paris and the most-visited paid monument in the world; 7.1 million people ascended it in 2011. The third level observatory's upper platform is at 279.11 metres the highest accessible to the public in the European Union. The tower received its 250 millionth visitor in 2010. Source: <b><a href"https:en.wikipedia.orgwikiEiffel_Tower" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Wikipedia.<a><b>

photo.description: Das Grand Palais ist ein für die Weltausstellung im Jahr 1900 in Paris errichtetes Ausstellungsgebäude. Es stellt mit dem gegenüberliegenden Petit Palais und der benachbarten Pont Alexandre III ein bedeutendes Architekturensemble der Belle Époque dar. Es entstand zwischen 1897 und 1900 an der ebenfalls neugeschaffenen Avenue Nicolas II. (heute: Avenue Winston Churchill). Aus einem auf französische Architekten beschränktem Wettbewerb gingen 1896 Henri-Adolphe-Auguste Deglane (1855–1931), Louis-Albert Louvet (1860–1936), Albert-Félix-Théophile Thomas (1847–1907) und Charles-Louis Girault (1851–1932) als Sieger hervor, wobei Letztgenannter die Leitung erhielt. Am 1. Mai 1900 fand die Einweihung des Grand Palais durch Präsident Émile Loubet statt. <a href"http:de.wikipedia.orgwikiGrand_Palais" rel"nofollow">de.wikipedia.orgwikiGrand_Palais<a> The Grand Palais des Champs-Elysées, is a large historic site, exhibition hall and museum complex located at the Champs-Élysées in the 8th arrondissement of Paris, France. Construction of the Grand Palais began in 1897 following the demolition of the Palais de l'Industrie (Palace of Industry) as part of the preparation works for the Universal Exposition of 1900, which also included the creation of the adjacent Petit Palais and Pont Alexandre III.The structure was built in the style of Beaux-Arts architecture as taught by the École des Beaux-Arts of Paris. The building reflects the movement's taste for ornate decoration through its stone facades, the formality of its floor planning and the use of techniques that were innovative at the time, such as its glass vault, its structure made of iron and light steel framing, and its use of reinforced concrete. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiGrand_Palais" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiGrand_Palais<a>

photo.description: Paris Exposition: Inauguration Day, Paris, France, 1900. Inauguration Day. The 'Ship of the President' or the President's Barge. President Loubet and his party embark to review the foreign pavilion and Pont Alexandre III after opening excercises. The buildings belonging to the Trocadero section are visible. The Palace of Animated Voyages with its circular balcony is clearly seen in the center. Brooklyn Museum Archives, <a href"http:www.brooklynmuseum.orgresearchdigital-collectionsgoodyear" rel"nofollow">Goodyear Archival Collection<a> (S03_06_01_014 image 9892). It helps us to know how our visitors work with our images, so if you use it, we'd love to know how! Drop us a line by leaving a comment here or email our archivist: library@brooklynmuseum.org
photo.tags: red seine river boats 1900 goodyear brooklynmuseum frenchflag parisexposition canalboatparis bm:uniques0306010149892
photo.title: Paris Exposition: Inauguration Day, Paris, France, 1900

photo.description: Paris Exposition: Seine River, Paris, France, 1900. The Seine from the Alexandre III bridge. In view is the Bridge of the Invalides as well as the Pavilion of the City of Paris on the right and the Italian Pavilion on the right. Brooklyn Museum Archives, <a href"http:www.brooklynmuseum.orgresearchdigital-collectionsgoodyear" rel"nofollow">Goodyear Archival Collection<a> (S03_06_01_015 image 2048). It helps us to know how our visitors work with our images, so if you use it, we'd love to know how! Drop us a line by leaving a comment here or email our archivist: library@brooklynmuseum.org
